December 25, 2005: Fiction
“S” IS FOR SILENCE, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95.) Kinsey
Millhone searches for a woman who disappeared 34 years ago.
MARY, MARY, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The F.B.I. agent Alex
Cross tracks a Hollywood killer who announces the crimes via e-mail.
AT FIRST SIGHT, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.95.) The young couple from
"True Believer," who are now expecting a child, receive a disturbing message.
PREDATOR, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) On the trail of a possible
serial killer, Dr. Kay Scarpetta turns to a jailed psychopath for advice.
LIGHT FROM HEAVEN, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $26.95.) Father Tim's bishop asks
him to revive a long-closed mountain church; the final novel in the Mitford series.
AMAZING PEACE, by Maya Angelou. (Random House, $9.95.) A poem read at
the lighting of the White House Christmas tree in December 2005.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A murder at the
Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery
of a secret society.
FOREVER ODD, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) Odd Thomas, a character from
Koontz's 2003 novel of the same name who can communicate with the dead,
searches for a missing friend.
THE LIGHTHOUSE, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $25.95.) Commander Adam
Dalgliesh is called in to solve a murder (or two) on a remote Cornish island.
CHRIST THE LORD: OUT OF EGYPT, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $25.95.) What
happened in Bethlehem; a story narrated by a 7-year-old who discovers that he is
the Prince of Peace.
THE CAMEL CLUB, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.95.) A group of eccentric
conspiracy theorists stumbles across an actual plot reaching to the highest levels
of government.
SON OF A WITCH, by Gregory Maguire. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $26.95.) Liir
makes his way through the dangerous land of Oz; a sequel to "Wicked."
THE CHRISTMAS HOPE, by Donna VanLiere. (St. Martin's/Integrity, $14.99.) A
social worker and her husband take a 5-year-old girl into their home.
THE REGIME: EVIL ADVANCES, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale,
$25.99.) The second prequel to the "Left Behind" series continues the story of the
rise of the Antichrist and follows the series' other major characters.
A FEAST FOR CROWS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $28.) In the aftermath
December 25, 2005
Non-Fiction
TEACHER MAN, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) The author of "Angela's
Ashes" remembers his years teaching high school English in New York City.
OUR ENDANGERED VALUES, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The
former president warns against blurring politics and fundamentalist religion.
TEAM OF RIVALS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) The
political genius of Abraham Lincoln, revealed in his relationship with his cabinet,
from the author of "No Ordinary Time."
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.)
A columnist for The New York Times analyzes 21st-century economics and
foreign policy and presents an overview of globalization trends.
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and
his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
1776, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) An account of America's
founding year by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, focusing on the inexperienced
George Washington and heroic citizen soldiers.
THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, by Joan Didion. (Knopf, $23.95.) The
author's attempts to come to terms with the death of her husband and the grave
illness of their only daughter.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
THE TRUTH (WITH JOKES), by Al Franken. (Dutton, $25.95.) A comic attack on
the Bush administration from the author of "Lies (and the Lying Liars Who Tell
Them)."
MY FRIEND LEONARD, by James Frey. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The author of the
addiction memoir "A Million Little Pieces" remembers a helpful mobster friend.
700 SUNDAYS, by Billy Crystal. (Warner, $21.95.) A childhood memoir from the
actor and entertainer, based on his Tony-winning play.
THE BEATLES, by Bob Spitz. (Little, Brown, $29.95.) A biography of four lads who
shook the world.
DEAN AND ME (A LOVE STORY), by Jerry Lewis and James Kaplan.
(Doubleday, $26.95.) The funnier half of Martin and Lewis remembers his time
with the man he calls "my partner."
THE EDUCATION OF A COACH, by David Halberstam. (Hyperion, $24.95.) A
profile of Bill Belichick, the coach of the New England Patriots.
